FIGURE 11-3
Possible Special Roles of Brands in the Brand Portfolio
1.To attract a particular market segment not currently being covered by other brands of the firm
2.To serve as a flanker and protect flagship brands
3.To serve as a cash cow and be milked for profits
4.To serve as a low-end entry-level product to attract new customers to the brand franchise
5.To serve as a high-end prestige product to add prestige and credibility to the entire brand portfolio
6.To increase shelf presence and retailer dependence in the store
7.To attract consumers seeking variety who may otherwise have switched to another brand
8.To increase internal competition within the firm
9.To yield economies of scale in advertising, sales, merchandising, and physical distribution
summary_markdown: Figure 11-3 outlines nine potential special roles that brands can fulfill within a firm's overall brand portfolio. These roles are categorized by their strategic objectives, including market penetration and segment coverage, such as attracting specific market segments not currently served or acting as a low-end entry-level product to draw in new customers. The figure also highlights defensive and supportive functions, like serving as a flanker to protect flagship brands or increasing shelf presence and retailer dependence. Furthermore, it details roles focused on financial and operational efficiency, such as acting as a cash cow for profit generation or yielding economies of scale in various business functions. Finally, some roles are geared towards enhancing brand perception and internal dynamics, including serving as a high-end prestige product to bolster the portfolio's credibility and increasing internal competition to drive performance.
